abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment for the
            Mali Multi-Sectoral HIV/AIDS Project focusing on a national
            plan for managing biomedical waste anticipates negative
            environmental impacts resulting from the plan's
            implementation and proposes measures to mitigate them. Some
            risks posed by the planned waste collection, treatment, and
            disposal include the following: Prevent water contamination,
            accidental pricking from sharps, and the infestation of
            disease-carrying insects by ensuring groundwater and surface
            water resources are kept separate from polluting sources,
            ensuring that the disposal site will not be used neither be
            used for either agricultural or residential purposes, and
            lining the site with a closed, impermeable layer. To avoid
            infection from recovering patients; the risk of the reuse
            and sale of contaminated syringes; the increase in the
            incidence of diseases like tetanus, typhoid, diarrhea,
            hepatitis B, and HIV/AIDS; and the outbreak of respiratory
            ailments and other infections among the general population
            because of transporting untreated solid waste matter to dump
            sites by cart or uncovered trucks, sort and segregate sharp
            waste at the source, use different containers from those
            used for household garbage, treat waste as appropriate,
            transport waste in covered vehicles identified by signage
            and traveling at restricted speeds. If disposal is by
            incineration there is a risk to nearby residential areas of
            air pollution from dioxins, heavy metals, and other
            combustible materials, and to personnel involved in waste
            disposal by incineration. To mitigate these risks, manage
            waste storage, set up a system to filter the smoke emitted;
            increase the height of the ventilation shaft/flume to permit
            the release of residual pollutants; monitor plastic
            material, glass and metal and other such materials, and
            contents under pressure to prevent the incinerator from
            dysfunction and toxic emissions or explosions; and direct
            personnel to wear protective clothing and gear. To minimize
            risks from burning waste in the open air such as the
            dispersion of highly resistant microorganisms as well as the
            increased incidence of respiratory infections and other
            infections connected with hospitals, the proliferation of
            disease carrying insects and rodents, and the diffusion of
            smoke containing noncombustible pollutants, obtain and
            manage adaptable elimination systems and treat the waste
            before burning.
